reviewText: This may be my first review of a game on steam.....ever?  That said, I feel it absolutely necessary to chime in on what may possibly be the most ENJOYABLE racing experience i've ever had.  Im 31 and have played just about every single racing game ever made and past favorites include somewhat niche titles such as Project Gotham(Previous favorite) to the hardcore more popular titles such as Forza and Gran turismo.\n\nIn a very simple sense, this is like Project Gotham Rally. Initially simple but near limitness challenge and opportunity for improvement.  A somewhat perfect balance of sim and arcade.  Its just ENJOYABLE.  I enjoy ever single race with the exception of most of the RWD cars(Yes I suck with them).  Some may claim it was designed as a pure sim but many elements such as the damage, wonky airtime antics, post jump landings, etc dont seem 100% authentic but its pretty obvious the game wouldnt be very enjoyable if you clipped a stone on your second turn and ripped the back half of your car off spreading parts all over the road essentially killing your run.  The game is certainly brutal enough and you can total your vehicle forcing a restart but you really have to beat the cars into the ground for them to become totalled as opposed to real life where something as simple as a small jump can reek havic on the car.  Jumps just feel way too smooth and I wish the cars bucked" a bit more as they landed depending on your trajectory but its all good
date: its keeps the momentum going and the experience fast and frantic without constant unpredictable wipeouts.\n\nOne final comment I want to make is something that stands out to me in nearly every race.  The game does a FANTASTIC job simulating speed.  Something I think every racing developer tries to nail but almost always doesnt.  If my memory serves me correct this was my main issue with Forza and just circuit racing games in general.  Maybe it just has something to do with driving on wide open roads as opposed the narrow

I honestly dont think I will ever go back to traditional racing after this.\n\nDiRT Rally has spoiled me in all the right ways and I have zero desire to play or try any other racing game in the forseeable future.  In the end

I just made my own raceseat and fittet it with a G27 Wheel and it's amazing. Racing for 3 hours and i am physically exhausted.

If you love Rally / Rally-Games AND you can race a car without constant full throttle you will get your moneys worth here.
This means, as this game (at least imo) counts as a simulation, you have to treat it like one. If you get off the track hard, you fail the stage, or at least get a recovery penalty so big, you consider the run failed just aswell.

I really recomend a steering wheel of some sort or at least a controller with feathering triggers (like the xbox pad).

PS: Ditches love cars. Give that ditch a car.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Version 0.9

This is the Rally game you've always wanted. Focused on pure point to point racing. No more Gymkhana.

After getting used to the physics in this game, going back to older DiRT games feel like arcade folly. There are 3 basic modes Rally, Hill-climb and recently the added Rally X Cross (which is the only mode wherein other cars share the road with you.)

Updates are frequent with new cars and tracks. Each track being a location with very specific road conditions and each rally being different sections of that track including the mirror versions of those different sections. Tarmac, snow/ice, loose gravel of varying sizes which all give a different feel when driving. Mud behaves differently than dry dirt as does the vehicle depending on your drivetrain. It'll make you want to buy a wheel if you didn't have one already.

Lots of assists and bonus credits for turning them off. For easy entry into the series but still very difficult to master. There are no more flashbacks making racing much more intense. In its stead is a time penalty of resetting your car back onto the track. A nice trade off is you can avoid this penalty by getting back onto the track yourself before the timer deems you unable to get back.

By far the most realistic entry into the series, I'd even extend that to all rally/off-road racing games; Graphically and more importantly the physics therein. Cars receive damage and even retain that damage through the races and must be repaired in between with possible time penalties for 'over repairing' beyond your given time to repair.

You will build a team, crew chief and other members. That get better and more efficient the more they work with you. Make sure you keep their contract up as these people you hire will allow you to fix more things in between races and keep your vehicle in tip top shape even if you aren't the best driver in the world.

This is quintessential if you're into off-road racing of any variety.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Truly awesome!

I don't know a super amount about rally, but I have played some really great rally games in the past, namely Rally Trophy and Rally Championships. But this... Dirt Rally... Has topped them all.

If you, like me, had the misfortune of playing Dirt 1/2/3, you probably won't be expecting much from Dirt Rally initially, but if you're looking for a proper rally simulation with outstanding sound quality and the real feel of flying down a dirt road with mud and water soaking your car as you pray you don't hit the tree up ahead, then you won't be dissapointed.

It's got it all:
- Excellent Graphics
- The best sound effects i've ever heard in a rally game
- Just absolutely gorgeously modelled tracks, from dried out greek dirt roads, the snowy hills of Sweden right down to the muddy Welsh moorlands.
- Large selection of cars that you actually want to drive! None of that random dirt buggy stuff from the previous Dirt games. Ford RS200, Ford Sierra, Peugeot 306, Mini classic, Lancia Delta Integrale and tons more.
- Oh! And no terrible cutscenes with a pro-active nobody telling you that this is your caravan and that great things await...

Codemasters have managed to go back to the nitty gritty roots at the core of Rally. Dirty, dangerous and hair raisingly exciting, and pack it all into a single game with a pretty low pricetag.

--I use a G27 wheel/h-shifter to drive with, it's well supported, the FFB is great with only a little left to be desired on tarmac imo, and it's really responsive--

Do I recommend this game? Let's put it this way. I would buy it again in a heartbeat. YES!

9/10 - Fantastic! THANK YOU FOR SAVING PC RALLY, CODEMASTERS! :D

In one sentence: Rally game made right.

In an analysis: This is the true successor to Colin MC'ray Dirt and any rally game before the DiRT series. It is rougthless, unforgiving, muddy, nerv-racking, rage inducing piece of awesomeness. You don't get any tutorial or some ♥♥♥***le that narates your every step like DiRT 3, it throws you in the pool without any warning and you will fight for your life and BY GOD you will fail without tomorrow and I mean it. You will crash, by god you will crash so many times that you will curse the time you bought it, but that's what is the BEST part of this game because you will try to get better. It doesn't have a difficulty setting, the difficulty comes with experience, because every car behavies completely different from the other and every stage have different effect on your driving. Your best chance of success comes from hearing your co-driver and your reaction time. I read of people bashing this game cause of the physics of the game is trash !!1" or "the updatez don't fix this or that". WRONG ! Every update makes the game even better than before

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I got a problem since I got this DiRT Rally...  I can't stop playing! hahahah
I never drive a rally sim before, just regular race sims...  but I saw a lot of RBR and others, I want to get some to try, but except for RBR the reviews are not so good.
Then this game came on steam, I saw some postive reviews, and decided to get it, and I don't regret!
It's amazing, very funny, challenging, addictive!
The technics to drive a rally car are some different. I'm liking to practice and get a bit better now since my first stages, but I still have  a lot to learn. It's very cool!
One positive aspect is it seems Codemasters are listen the public, the foruns are crowded and the devs are open to feedbacks.
The game is in early access now, but already playable, and we hope its getting even better over the time.
If you like race sims, and want to race rally way, give it a try, good chances you'll like it.

reviewText: When i was a small boy i saw a WRC race on the TV, and after that i was hooked. The way these professional rally drivers took corners effortlessly, flew over jumps as if they actually had wings and how the miraculously came out of ever spectacular tumble un-harmed. So being the naive little boy i was i went out and bought DiRT 1, and it was the best game i ever owned, and soon after that DiRT 2 came along and blew me away with its imersive campaign mode and vast amount of cars. When i grew older and entered my teens I was looking for a more challenging game than DiRT 1 or 2; as i have mastered them completely. I remember the day i bought Dirt 3, another adventure in a box just waiting for my teenage hands to learn the mystery of GYMKHANA. So you could imagine my excitement stumbling upon a page witin the DiRT Reddit annoucing the new game DiRT Rally". I had the amazing chance to help the DiRT community to create the new version of my favorite game
date: a real dream come true. Long story short DiRT Rally won't be just a game to me

THE GREATEST SIMULATOR OF ALL TIME

DiRT Rally captures the essence of what makes rally unique – that sense of trying to remain in control of your emotions, as you hurtle along dangerous, undulating roads at breakneck speed, aiming to squeeze everything out of your car whilst knowing that one crash could irreparably harm your stage time. It’s the ultimate test of a driver’s skill, and it’s the ultimate in high risk, high reward gameplay.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(9/09/2015) - http://steamcommunity.com/id/tgchan/recommended/310560/



Hello everyone,

I will keep updating this review with new thoughts and incoming updates. First of all, I AM ALL TO THE PAIN SIM DRIVER! (I was so afraid to buy this game because of ARCADISH style of previous ones - FEAR NOT and buy now !)

Few years of Richard Burns Rally (raw, rsrbr, rbr-world), iRacing, Live for Speed etc. I will write some more in free time - I have to rally some more now!




THE GOOD:
+ soft-lock is a great feauture~! (you don't have to set rotation of your wheel for each car, you put it on max and the game will do the rest, fixing it to a current driven car)
+ Rally Cross mode is plenty of fun. The cars feel much better than the ones from rally mode, a bit too slippery though, it feels like driving on ice most of the time
+ dashcam is way to go, forget the cockpit view if you strive for the maximum realism. It looks and feels amazing~! I just wish more cars would have shift-light and gear inf box located higher so we could see them in this view
+ 306 Maxi + German special stages on tarmac are so much fun
+ driving on a rim (without a tyre) is not fun :)
+ with higher difficulty, the weather conditions get worse (night, snow, rain etc.) Unfortunately, only your visibility is affected... the handling stays the same...
+ I can't get enough of how rain looks like... simply amazing
+ WRC Ford Fiesta handles beautifully on Welsh stages!
+ night + heavy rain = heaven!
+ amazing lighting work; it looks so incredible when you are driving through shaded areas and the bright sun rays are falling into your cockpit
+ if you hold the handbrake with RWD cars without clutch you can stall them, yea!
+ your gears can pop out, if you have damaged gearbox!!!
+ daily, weekly and monthly online events where you can't restart! YEA!!!
+ sounds!
+ graphics (about which, I really don't care - but it looks amazing)
+ overall pleasure from rallying!
+ I expected much worse
+ water-splash is so sick!!!
+ car repairs
+ sense of speed
+ it is already much better than RBR!!! Can you believe it!? No?! Me too! BUT IT IS - trust me!
+ I can't stop rallying already and I am driving the slowest car~!
+ great animations of cockpit, you can see your feet working on gas, brake and clutch pedals
+ logitech g27 @ 540* works like a charm!
+ SS (special stages) look amazing!



THE BAD:
- NOT EVEN CLOSE TO RICHARD BURN'S RALLY! ARCADY AS F*CK... It is far far away from being a simulator... It is plenty of fun but I don't think it will even come close to RBR...
- zero respect for the speed... you can drive 100km/h, hit a tree and still drive without any consequence... PATHETIC!
- [PARTIALLY FIXED - all surfaces feel weird] during the rain, you can't tell the difference between wet and dry surface... ARCADE BS!
- zero respect for Monte Carlo stages... too much grip... too easy... ARCADE BS!
- you can barely slide the car unless you use a handbrake...
- [FIXED - clutch override option added] there is no MANUAL SEQUENTIAL GEARBOX + MANUAL CLUTCH... which is real WRC car setup
- the power of WRC MINI on tarmac is some kind of a bad joke...
- you start rolling after a great crash and the game resets you on the road... stop with this arcade BS!
- terrible ARCADE DAMAGE SYSTEM! You can literally bounce back from walls... - bring the deadly one from RBR!!! No mercy for arcade noobs !
- when you fell out of a road, it takes one button to recover... WTF!? It should be at least 30sec of penalty!

THE UGLY:
~ [PARTIALLY FIXED... still not fair]=[all cars except for WRC have now delay when using sequential gearbox, very good idea] people driving with full manual setups and zero assists ( h-pattern + manual clutch = it is so much HARDER ) should not be thrown into bag with other drivers using different easier setups.
~ the cars slow down way too fast when you are not accelerating!
~ not enough stages in my opinion. Even though the location are very nice, they get boring rather quickly...
~ [PARTIALLY FIXED... still feels slugish]=[latest ffb patch made it so detailed, I don't know if I should rally or admire how nice it is! Now you read the car behaviour instead of fighting with a wheel. Feels amazing! The car is ALIVE!!!] FFB feels like I am driving every car without a power steering, I constantly have to fight with my wheel... after 13h+ of rallying it is so bloody annoying!
~ [FIXED]=[latest ffb patch made it so detailed, I don't know if I should rally or admire how nice it is! Now you read the car behaviour instead of fighting with a wheel. Feels amazing! The car is ALIVE!!!] definitely needs more details in handling (although some icy parts of the road were amazing and they have sent me straight into a wall)
~ how can you not let us change different tyres for different surfaces!? It is rally FFS!
~ [FIXED]=[latest ffb patch made it so detailed, I don't know if I should rally or admire how nice it is! Now you read the car behaviour instead of fighting with a wheel. Feels amazing! The car is ALIVE!!!] FFB needs to be much more detailed, it feels very sluggish at the moment - still nice though
~ [PARTIALLY FIXED... the gears still pop out randomly]=[they pop out now only when gearbox is damaged or when you have not pressed clutch all the way down during a gear change] gears from my H-pattern pop out from time to time; not sure if bug or simulator thingy



* After more than 63 hrs on record of rallying in Dirt Rally, I have found myself missing the real professional sim... and started racing in iRacing again, even though I do not like track racing. This game is really good, and plenty of fun, but it is as close of being a simulator as Counter-Strike is... It will never be a sim, everyone with a little piece of working brain, can see where this is heading... Do I still have a hope for it to become one? No, not anymore. This is nothing more but a good arcade rally game. If they will keep advertising this as a sim, I will change my review drastically, they do not deserve this word SIMULATOR, describing this title!


** After 67 hrs on record, I am too irritated with stiff handling and almost none existent weight balance to continue... As I said before, it is only an arcade game and they have no idea about simulations... I want to punch them in the face for talking about simulating a drop in power, on high elevated special stages, when they let you hit a wall at the maximum speed without any consequence... This is not the biggest problem though, you are not taking pleasure from hitting walls, right? Rally is all about the skilfull handling of the car, the way you do it, you balance the weight of the car. Unfortunately, you can't feel it, in this game at all. The physics feel off, cars are too stiff, unresponsive, underpowered and god knows what else... Even the sound of the cars became dull and boring after a while... Those are rally cars god damn it! Let them sound like monsters!


Now, I can clearly say that RBR is still no. 1, such a shame...


EDIT: After coming back from a month or so break, game feels amazing again. The RallyCross is fun and the cars actually feel like the WRC should have... It is a great game... I am just angry because I know it can be the best rally simulator ever created, I just hate the idea that they are trying to please both; arcade turds and sim freaks like myself... Unfortunately because of this, the games falls somewhere in between... Too hard for total arcade noobs, and too arcady for a real simulator... What a shame...



More incoming soon!


Thanks for reading


--
tgchan.com

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been on the look for a legit racing simulator for quite some time and i think this game is it.

- Physics replicate road and tire feel very well and It is actually quite hard and challenging, not for those looking for arcade/relaxing style easy drive.
- Driving the courses/cars requires proper concentration or you'll end up being losing time, smashed up, mental inconsistence, or disqualified for severe vehicular injury.
- Drive as if you would in real life, loss of friction, bumps, road camber, etc. requires careful throttle, brake control, etc.. Learning curve is very high especially if not use to rally and can be a little frustrating but I personally would not want it any other way for a game like this.
- Excellent environment providing all of it's elements including ice, rain, snow, dawn, night time racing with functional headlights and more.
- No need to really go into further details, it is as close to Rallying as you can get without actually being in a rally. Even the co-drivers voice has a sense of urgency under fast technicals and can hear some shakiness in voice on uneven/bumpy terrain. Maybe it's my imagination as once you put your concentration into the game it gets intense, but voice for slower parts of the course does seem more calmly put.

game 10/10 for an early access with well executed content so far.

I do think the game can get a little more real to induce more awareness and caution i.e.) sometimes you can smack rocks and trees and keep going. /shrug

My game runs extremely fluid with minimal fps drop and if it does it'll not affect my experience. I have game on ULTRA.
i5 quad 3.5
GTX 970 Nvidia
8gb RAM

This game has me considering even putting out for a logitech g27.. game is that good of a driver imo. I've been playing with Xbox One controller thus far and tuning it to run properly is very hard as a controller cannot beat the pedal travel and the stick cannot replicate a steering wheel at the slightest. (Often times you end up full lock either direction on the control stick, or I just don't have the finesse to finely move the stick minute amounts to deliver low steering angle...) I have played shortly on a wheel set up and I think it does this game the much needed justice over the controller and especially the keyboard. If this game does come out for console, I'm sure they'll have the game calibrated to easily accomodate controllers.

I cannot comment on the multiplayer as I've yet to try it, also hoping for more cars, environments, and tuning options of course. I've also not checked either steam or their main forums but I hear from other reviews before I bought the game that developers are very much looking to bring the best rallying simulation possible and I hope they keep it as real as possible for future as well. This shows with their constant updates from a outside looker point of view.

*Caution: this game may not appeal to ricers as you cannot
- Slam the cars
- Stretch the tires
- Run -20 camber with the said above

but you can and will scrape; as a bonus, possibly brake an oil pan =P

Couple of tips:
- DO NOT CUT, there are solid obstacles or big gaps that it's possible to destroy your car completely or severely injuring it for the remainder of the race.
- Look ahead, if you see some major openings to set yourself up for speed do it

reviewText:
First off, I am a long time PC racing simmer, going back to the early Papyrus days with Indianapolis 500. These days I race with an Obutto Ozone cockpit, G27 wheel and pedals, and a Fanatec Clubsport Shifter SQ.

Let me just say that Dirt Rally is a superb game and racing sim in most respects. If you have interest in rally racing (both modern rally and vintage/historic rally,) it's a safe bet that you will more than get your money's worth out of the game. So now to break it down a bit more:

Pros:
-Wide variety of cars, broken down into very interesting categories such as 60's FWD, 80's RWD, Group B 4WD, and so on.
-Each car behaves uniquely, even among cars in the same classification
-SUPERB sound design; close your eyes while watching a replay and you'll swear you're watching a Youtube clip of a real rally stage.
-Five beautifully modelled countries to race in, including Greece, Monaco, Wales, Germany, Finland, and Sweden.
-Fully modelled Pikes Peak, including before full paving (partial dirt road) and after full paving (all asphalt)
-Rally cross tracks, with online multiplayer
-Realistic handling and force feedback effects (the physics and FFB are not hardcore sim quality like iRacing or Assetto Corsa, but certainly lean FAR more towards sim more than arcade)
-Time of day and weather settings for all tracks, which provide gameplay variation and challenge

Cons:
-Needs more rally stages, because you'll start to recognize sections quite quickly as play each stage more and more
-The rally cross and Pikes Peak stuff is neat, but feels tacked on (a bit of the old Dirt games, in a way)
-The interface is clunky; although it's been improved greatly since the first Early Access release, it's still not intuitive and will take some getting used to
-As good as the sounds are (best in class by a long shot, really) there are a lot of minor issues, such as silent turbos in all of the turbocharged cars, at least on my 5.1 system

This is an all around fantastic game, and I can't say enough good things about how the developers have listened to customer feedback from the beginning. I'm very hopeful that they will create some DLC with more countries or stages to rally in, and more vehicles to enjoy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The mechanics in this game feel excellent, it runs smoothly, and it feels like an accurate simulation of actual driving.

I play full manual with H-shifter & clutch on a Logitech G27 wheel (which the game picked up and configured the settings for perfectly) and the force feedback and wheel return is pretty much perfect. They seem to be adding new content fairly regularly, all of which so far has been of a very high quality.

It's early access so there's a couple of small bugs here and there as of writing this review which I'm sure will get fixed, but nothing major. Alt tabbing the game means it switches to windowed mode which is annoying, and starting without launch control sometimes results in a jumped start even though I'm in neutral with the handbrake on. Otherwise I haven't noticed any other bugs and it hasn't crashed once.

This is the best realistic driving game around right now, and one of the only games I would recommend buying in early access. They are doing early access right.

reviewText:
I bought an old Microsoft Sidewinder Force 2 USB directional force feedback joystick used on eBay after playing Dirt 3 and loving the game, but feeling like the controls were way too similar to old console games from the 90s back before analog sticks came around.

Back in the late 90s, I started a computer store and I used to sell the Logitech brand of directional force feedback wheels and sticks.  Logitech had the best hardware ever brought to the consumer market when it came to the sticks and the cables and the motors.  It made a decent racing/flying game an absolutely riviting experience.  To give an idea of why directional force feedback matters, try getting into a go-kart at a local kart racing place.  Just rent a kart and go around the track.  That wheel will fight you around every turn, and it makes the driver/road connection a real wrestling match.  This is also what it is like racing a full sized vehicle off road, on gravel, or on dirt.  When you push a vehicle to the limits of traction and beyond, that wheel becomes quite a bear to content with but it also gives you feedback about what the vehicle is doing that is less obvious otherwise.

So feedback like this makes a racing experience more real.  Cool.  In addition, the tiny little sticks that most consoles use (like the 360 controller) don't have the fine degree of control that something like racing needs.  The tiny sticks are great when it comes to analog direction, but not so great when it comes to distance between center and fully pressed in a given direction.  This isn't important for all games, but the shortcoming becomes obvious in situations like racing.

I play games sitting on the couch, with a projector screen in my living room connected to my PC.  This means a wheel and pedals would be quite cumbersome, because I have no desk to clamp such a monster to.  My experience with wheels is that they are often less precise than a large joystick, and certainly less precise than an actual hydraulic/cable driven steering wheel from a car or kart.

All this is why I bought this joystick.  I bought such an old one because they don't make large, directional force feedback analog sticks like this anymore as near as I can tell, the market trends just aren't pushing them.  This old stick requires no drivers in Windows 7 x64, so it really is plug and play.  The old Logitech stick I used to own/sell is technically superior, but it isn't compatible with newer flavors of Windows so it isn't an option anymore.

As to the experience, I actually bought Dirt Rally after having some difficulty setting it up with Dirt 3, seeing that Dirt Rally just came out, and reading an interview that says they added analog stick support to the default controller profiles set up for Dirt Rally.  I did get joystick support and directional feedback working with Dirt 3, but it just feels wrong, and it needs to be tuned in some manner because it will literlally throw me off the road even when I have the force dialed back to a mere 10% in the game.  The force reduction doesn't seem to work and the motors are strong enough to literally muscle you off the road, if the game/stick aren't tuned or tunable to work well together.

I did have to go in and set the stick and the throttle (built into the stick) as needed so Dirt Rally knew what to do with it but once I did, the motors in the stick snapped to life and the stick was suddenly ready to go (it sits in a relaxed state with the stick lounging to the side until a game talks to it).

I jumped into the first track, with the first car.  WOW!  Not only did it bring back memories of playing on my old analog stick and driving racing games like Need for Speed or Star Wars Pod Racing, even better, it reminded me of getting behind the wheel of an actual vehicle and carefully driving around mountain roads as I get a feel for how far I can safely push the vehicle.  I wasn't fast.  I wasn't a speed demon.  It felt like driving a real vehicle.  It wasn't relaxing, it was edge of your seat stuff!  I nearly felt like I had left my house, and had an adventure as I get a feel for gravel roads, as the feedback goes from pushing against you gently, to pushing harder, to going slack when you slingshot past a spot and know if your angle of entry wasn't good you are in trouble because the steering went slack due to a sudden and temporary complete lack of traction.

This game isn't flashy.

It isn't about eye candy.

Tracks take longer, like real driving does.

This is the game that gets you into racing.

This is the game that gets you into racing games.

This game is the reason you get better controllers.

Kudos, and thanks for getting me back into racing, and giving me a reason to get into force feedback that is more than mere rumbles!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this on prerelease with a little concern given how hit or miss codemasters can be (Dirt Showdown anyone?) and didn't want a racing game aimed at the console crowd where a gamepad plays better than a wheel after all the assists are added. This game amazes with great physics, beautiful graphics, and a challenging set of race stages. It might be too sim-like and complicated for children with the extensive car set-ups and difficult runs, but the cars drive so realistically with a wheel (g27 here) it is incredibly immersive and provides a compelling racing experience.

The cons are that it is still pre-release at this time and while the online challenges provide a sort of multiplayer, it still doesn't have true multiplayer races which I will be disappointed if they don't add eventually. And I'll be annoyed if this is all you get and the additional promised content will be DLC that you have to purchase after the official" release of the game. Nevertheless
date: for the prerelease cost it is an awesome game that is worth buying if you like driving games with realistic physics and great graphics. My feeling is that the work Codemasters put into the physics paid off and they have a winner in this genre."

reviewText:
In one word: 'Dirt!'
10/10 Best Rally simulation ever built!
Would rip wheels from Mini Cooper with 12km of stage left again!!!

This game truly represents a back to basics hardcore experience that places you in the front seat and incontrol of a rally team; where you take this team is entirely left to you from car purchases, to upgrades, the engineers performing this upgrades, graphs galore and other slight car attenuations to match the race car to your needs!

This game brings racing simulation for the off road motorsports fan into a new generation, its doesn't require small crowd shiny things such as short tracks, big name narration or more recent additions such as gymkhana and drift... Why? Because all you need is some DiRT (And Ice, Snow, mirror deep Mud to name a few) to Rally on, at the edge of your seat for a white knuckle expereince attempting to hold your car onto the track... so what if 3 of its 4 tires are down and flat, with only 1 tire still up... it doesn't matter as it's just bounced off with your wheel down the embankment! (Who knew you could rip the wheels of a Mini Cooper)

The game challenges you to rethink the tactics we've grown used to and that is done so simply its beautiful and it will leave you hanging for more after some short stage recovery. The stages are incredibly intense!

This game changes what you know, what we know about Rally games and challenges you to push past its clasp of simulation as it removes the best DiRT Rally games into arcade bins as it creates new standards.

Great physics, awesome sound effects, wicked cockpit simulations it's as real as you get and the best bit... No micro transactions... once you buy this game its yours, all of its content and its ongoing updates by the developers that listen to their community! Codemaster you've outdone yourself!!!

Drive safe!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First things first, this isn't your average rally game, this is hardcore tough rallying.

If you are looking for a relaxing racing game, this isn't it you should probably get DiRT 3.

First of all the graphics are stunning and the performance is awesome, I use a AMD Radeon R9 270 2GB graphics card and get a solid 60FPS at all times.

Now to the gameplay. You need money and points to progress through the game. If you damage your car it isn;t easy to repair it, you have limited re-starts and the AI is difficult to beat. It is a hard game to get into and you need to listed to call outs and get a feeling for the game

I woudl highly recomend a controller or a Steering wheel as it is almost impsoible to use a mouse and keyboard to play this game.

It would be nice to see a dificulty setting and a unlimited carrer mode where you can have any car in whatever championship. The rally aspect of the game is really good, I do really enjoy it. However the hill climbing, not so much. The hilly climbing cars are far to powerful and spinn out whenever you go near the throttle i think there needs to be an rookie" setting for this game mode as I find it very hard to do and most of the time I jsut quit out of frustration.

Overall I would recommend this game but only if you are looking for an hardcore rally if you ae looking for a game that is easier and a bit more fun with more veriety I would highly recommend DiRT 3. I have it and I love it

reviewText:
5 reasons why you should get DiRT Rally, now!

5. You would feel like a rally driver. Suggest to turn up your air conditioning when driving in snow in order to have the maximum effect.

4. It is realistic and beautiful. I turn off all the assist and auto-gearbox, just like in F1. Except, this is more fun than F1 games. Also getting rewarded in-game for playing it the hard way. Restart is discouraged. Basically just move forward after a big mistake, like real racing.

3. It is mind boggling that the same company that made that crappy F1 game (OK not all iterations are crappy) is the one that made this brilliant racing game. Perhaps what people say about geniuses are true. It is a matter of hits and misses.

2. I play with PS3 controller (in PC and it's great). I don't race well. It can be hard. But I get to enjoy the journey and experience. Woohoo!

1. I am more grateful to what I have in life, more thankful having those who are around me. After seeing a few near-death experience here and there (man, those cliffs), I see life differently.

What about cons and suggestions? Here are two.

A) I need a female co-pilot. I mean, if I am to hear a voice yelling to my head all the time, I would prefer a female voice.

B) Why is there no Singapore flag :( Fortunately I was born in Hong Kong. At least that is representated in the game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nMe, as a amateur co-driver and rally enthusiast find this game no doubt the next gen rally simulator. Of course its still WIP and raw, but i see great potential. It's really hard to go fast, and when you go, mistakes are easy to come, but i enjoy the feeling when you push 101% in the woods of UK for 10 stages in a row, just to win rally by matter of seconds. Of course there are some flaws, like when hiting a snow bank in Monte Carlo rally, then it feels like hiting concrete fall. There are also some pacenotes call out and corner speed mistakes, but hey, even in real life co-drivers use to make these mistakes. You guys from Dirt Rally development crew, keep up the good work and set the next benchmark for driving simulators!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

DiRT Rally is one of those simulator games where players can gain an appreciation of how freaking difficult it is to be a rally driver. Seriously, it must take some massive genitalia to be able to drive this fast.

Some notes for you all;

-RWD cars slip and slide like it's constantly raining, and that's just on the gravel/asphalt tracks.
-You MUST throw the car into corners to get it to turn, but too much and it launches into the wall.
-After attempts at what must have been 100 hairpin turns, I finally managed to pull off a scandinavian flick and I was f***ing proud of myself.
-Playing with a controller (xbox/ps4) helps immensly, and if you have a racing wheel, it makes driving so much easier.
-DO NOT ATTEMPT TO DRIVE THE HILLCLIMB CARS AT ALL - I repeat, the hillclimb cars only start pulling at 5000-6000 RPM and scream up until their max RPM, where you are forced to change gears after only moving 10 metres. But hell they're fun.
-Driving in Manual is way too much fun, don't even bother starting with automatic if you want a challenge.

Hell, after writing all of this I want to go try a stage without crashing. Maybe.

One heck of a game that will keep getting better as time goes on.

reviewText:
This game is a masterpiece, simply said. All simulators should look up to this. Over a year has passed since Early Access, and we all saw this game evolve. There were monthly updates and constant patches that brought this game to it's full glory. Constantly adding new cars and tracks, tweaks and new game modes. This game has really realistic engine, cars are badass, from early '60s to Modern Beasts, it has it all. It has rally on every type of surface (Dirt,Gravel,Snow,Tarmac,Ice..) , to every weather condition possible (Sunny,Rain,Snowy,Fog...). Career mode is well designed and really entertaining, making you start rally with '60 vehicles, and then you slowly progress trough generations of cars. There is hillclimb, featuring Pikes Peak, 20km huge hillclimb. In hillclimb there is 2 car classes and 3 types of surfaces. Also there is WorldRX also known as RallyCross, where you have 3 classes (Since  of Console Release) and RallyCross also has Multiplayer feature. This game currently has 6 Rallys and 9 car classes ('60s, '70s, '80s, Group B [AWD], Group B [RWD], Group A, F2 Kit Car, R4, 2000s, 2010s). So yeah this game has everything for everyones taste. Game is really difficult, winning a stage on this game, not rally, a stage makes you fell like you are on top of the world. Game is really unforgiving and requires huge skill and lots and lots of practise! If you are a car lover, this is a must have!
Verdict: Amazing
+ Lots of Content for Everyones Taste
+ Challenging Experience
+ Simulation
+ Visuals, Sound and Gameplay are Amazing
+ Brilliant Handling

reviewText:
Edit: FULL RELEASE (short 'n' sweet review).

Utterly brilliant package, can't fault it really. My below EA impressions summarise the feel and flow of the game well enough so I don't want to repeat myself.

Really impressed with the sheer amount of content for the price too, lots of different cars and locations on offer. Codies back at their absolute best!

10/10, cracking game. Best virtual driving experience I've had in years.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

FIRST IMPRESSIONS:
Disclaimer... I would hardly call myself an expert but I've been driving things fast since I could reach a steering wheel. Mostly karts, with the odd single-seater and tin-top hoon.

+Handling: This thing is hard to master, and I ♥♥♥♥ing love it. The handbrake is my new best friend. I've genuinely not had this much fun with virtual driving in a long time, it's just so involving and physical. It's easy to get going at a somewhat competent pace, but to effectively carry speed you need to go full Finland. Pretty much the closest I've personally felt a game has come to a true driving 'experience' anyway.

+Presentation: Slick as ♥♥♥♥, functional, tidy. Does what you want it to fast, and it's very easy to navigate. I love the Colin McRae 2.0-style car outlines, and the doodle pace note icons. It feels like a true-to-heart, wonderfully British rally experience. Awesome stuff.

+Stages: Perfect in length, and there's already enough variety in there to keep me busy for a while. They're just long and different enough to keep me on my toes, but not so much that I can't pick it up and start zoning out from pace notes after a few attempts. I hate being overly attentive to them anyway.

+Cars: I was surprised by the decent selection we have to kick off with considering the price, good stuff. Seems like a no-messing attempt to get the best rally vehicles possible so that's fine by me. I like how it's split into decades too, nice sense of progression (not just with age but speed!).

+Sound/Graphics: I've seen a lot of praise for the former but honestly, both of these seem a minor at best improvement over the stellar Dirt 3. Not a bad thing, I've just not been blown away visually as yet. It's nice and clean though, does what it needs to do. I like the co-driver voice, sounds like a top bloke.

ISSUES SO FAR:
- FFB can feel a little muted at times.
- DFGT wheel seems to not be recognised every now and again, and the resultant pause messes with the steering lock / overall FFB feel. Restarting sorts it.
- All audio drops out if I try to play with the 60's Lancia. No idea why.

OVERALL:
Whether you're an old-school Codies fan or mildly interested in the rally genre, you owe it to yourself to give this a shot. Seriously, expecially for the price, it's ♥♥♥♥ing good.

reviewText:
Hands down one of the best driving games I have ever had the pleasure of owning. Would I recommend this to you? If you're looking for a challenging driving experience, I would say go for it.

The game speaks for itself in a lot of ways. It doesn't hold your hand. The only way you're going to get a podium finish in this game is if you fight for it. But the satisfaction of finally getting there is part of what makes this game so great.

I've never focused more in a video game than I have in DiRT Rally. Whether it's in the lush countryside of Germany or the steep rocky trails of Greece, they all have one thing in common; the courses are beautiful. The level of detail in this game is astonishingly well done. The courses presented are true to life and do an excellent job of capturing the scenery. I've found myself slowing down a few times just to admire the view. Whether that view is of the landscape or the car I'm driving, it's always a treat.

This game has a lot more to offer than just good visuals. With 39 cars available, ranging from the 60s to modern, there is something here for everyone (personally I can't get enough of the 95' Impreza). While all the cars aren't terribly different from one another, at least not in the same category, they each have their own little personality that can make you love them or hate them.

Alongside the career mode that you can progress through, there are also daily, weekly, and monthly leaderboard challenges. These really help the longevity of the game since it's literally infinite challenges. You can also just create your own tournaments or do quick runs on a chosen course(s).

If there's one thing I can say that disappointed me with DiRT Rally, it's the number of courses. After you spend many hours with the game, you start to learn locations by heart. Suddenly your co-driver becomes more of a nuisance than a valuable guide. It loses a little of its luster after that. I understand that recreating iconic courses like this is very expensive and time consuming, but it's a little disappointing nonetheless.

This is one of the games I hope they release DLC for. I would gladly fork out some cash for some more content of this quality.

tl;dr

One of the best rally experiences ever created. Get it if you're a rally fan and are up for a challenge.

The game is still being updated as part of Early Access, and it still has some issues and missing basic PC features such as mouse menu support, but overall for an Early Access game it is very well polished.

If you are looking for a great Rally and Rallycross game you won't find a better one on the market then DiRT Rally.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Before you read into this, note:
I do not own a wheel.
However, prior to buying DiRT Rally, I had a go with my brothers set (MOMO Black, popular back in the day). The driving felt pretty comfortable. Didn't have any problems with it besides that I'm an inexperienced sim driver and sucked at it, but for that short moment I had so much fun. The feeling threw me back somewhere in time I hazily remember playing Live For Speed and sucking at that, too. But most importantly, it felt real.

Seriously don't try this with keyboard ...
For now, I have to make do with a controller only. Mind you, this one is so cheap it doesn't even have the analog bumpers like a ps3/4 or x360 /XO controller, but your mileage may vary (no pun intended). The settings offer full keymapping for every input type, this is great. Main input devices are keyboard, gamepad, or wheel and pedals (I guess there's no reason not to play this with a flight stick or guitar hero controller if you really wanted to.. (update: tried, guitar controller definitely works)) and basic gamepad/controller is the middleground here. Manageable, in my case. I, like many others, would recommend that you shouldn't start this game with a keyboard, at the very least go grab a controller from your favourite console and you are set, maybe after minimal control tweaking. The defaults are impractical, imho.




I might update this review when I get more hours into the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been looking for a rally simulation game for a while.  I've played Richard Burns Rally, but it's pretty outdated now.  Dirt Rally is awesome.  Tons of control on setting up the car.  Very different performance characteristics between FWD, RWD and 4WD cars.  The courses are all based on real locations and are very well done.  There are some bugs here and there, but I've just been really enjoying it.  The courses are the biggest thing to me.  I've been following WRC for the past couple years and been to the Pikes Peak HC so it was very important to me that a simulation game match real life and I have to say it's excellent.  I can even identify the spots on Pikes Peak where I've spectated.  Really cool.

Love the game.

reviewText:
Wow. Just Wow.

What a fantastic game. I have been so bored with recent racing games. They feel so vanilla.

This game feels like my old Peugeot 205 GTi or my recent Peugeot 405 T16. Brutal if driven wrong, beyond rewarding if driven right. There are so many moments, where just like in a real car, you flinch for the brake and pray the car turns in, but it just understeers like a dog into a tree and ruins your entire race, just like the real thing would. So nice to feel like you're really driving a car :)

Have to say though, the top spec cars absolutely require a wheel and pedals. You just can't drive them with a digital accelerator! Damn right as well. Most cars are just fine, and even brilliant fun with a keyboard :)

Anyways. Bravo! Top notch game, worth ever damn cent.


EDIT: There are 2 annoying aspects to the game.
1. The co-driver calls are widly inaccurate at times. I've had a corner called as a 5" to find it's a vicious "2"! Bit annoying when you're ripping up a course.
2. The tiny ripple of gravel on the edge of the road (Wales you ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥!) will flip your car like a playing card. It just doesnt feel like a natural response..."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game might be early access (actually it is and I really hope for more content and improvements) but it's already on his way to be a masterpiece.
Definitely the MOST IMMERSIVE driving game I've ever tried.
Everything makes the immersion to such a high level: the rattling sound of dirt and small rocks hitting the bottom of the car, the copilot's voice getting more excited and fast paced in the most daunting part of the tracks, the water droplets hitting your windshield, the attention to details such as road signs, animals, houses, the reflection of the sun/moon in puddles, but even more it's the FEELING of the car.
This game truly makes you feel the car on each and every surface: different behaviour for different sources, different cars, different tuning and even based on different weather conditions.
You want to feel  something that will make your heart race? Try a stage at night with rain in a powerful beast like the Delta Integrale... you'll find yourself holding your breath and twisting and turning your body at every turn!

Fully recommended!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In my early access review I said that this game wasn't better than RBR. Now that this game has got brand new handling system and steering wheel support, I can happily say that Richard Burns Rally (published in 2004) has finally got another game to it's side in the legendary group of rally racing games. The handling is perfect for a steering wheel (I've got CSR Forza wheel), and the graphics and physics are awesome. This game is totally a simulation, not a crappy arcade game with cars going on rails like the older Dirt games. Although if you don't have a controller or a steering wheel, this game might be too hard for you. Just saying, the carreer mode is really hard.

Another point I'd like to say, is that this game has free (YES, LITERALLY FREE) updates every month. I just hope they keep updating the game. If done so, this game will have a long lifespan.

TL;DR: Awesome game, everything's good.

Thank you codemasters for making this game.

reviewText:
This and Toybox Turbos are both examples of what Codemasters can do when they rein in the budgets and give their titles focus. Both titles benefit, and we finally get to see another fully realistic rally game as a result. The controls have no weird kinks, there's no overlong segues between menus, it's just pick how long you wanna race for, pick the car you wanna race in and a loading screen later you're on a track.

You might be scared into thinking that a fully realistic rally game would demand a several-thousand-dollar Fanatec setup, but I've been playing this game on a cheap Ikea desk with a Logitech gamepad for half a year and I can get top-100 times using just that. It takes practise, sure, but no more than on that complex sim setup.

This game is now out of Early Access, and there's two main gameplay modes: Time trials on special stages, as in classic rally tradition; and Rally Cross, that being a six-car race on a short track with a mix of on-road and off-road sections. There's no tutorial, this game relies entirely on its progression mechanics as a way to teach you. You get just enough money to buy a slow 1960s car and you get pitted against other equally slow 1960s cars. The game also makes it explicit that you have no chance to win your first few championships by having you earn upgrades every time you use your car, its way of saying that it's okay to take it slow and just learn how to handle the machine you're in. Those first stages become oddly relaxing, and an exercise in just learning the track and the car.

There's other similarly relaxing mechanics in place. You start with a mechanics team who can't properly mend your car after a stage, and you won't be able to pay for one for some time. You're forced to make the decision between driving fast and suffering on a later stage, or driving slow and- oh hold on, I got a better time. That's the beauty of it, the game teaches you to drive slow without ♥♥♥♥ing up, and thereby saving you tens of seconds.

Contrast this with Dirt 2 and Dirt 3. You'd start with cars that go too fast, handle terribly, your only clue for how to drive is a literal rainbow road and instead of a proper tutorial or forcing you to learn your car, those games just had a mulligan button. As soon as you learned how that first car drove, every car after would be a cakewalk. Dirt Rally shows that you can have proper teaching tools AND be fun AND be a completely realistic simulation at the same time, and it's very much to Codemasters' credit for achieving that.

There's some excellent asymmetric multiplayer going on. The last few Codemasters games did have online leaderboards but this game takes that aspect and really runs with it. You can create your own league where your friends can join in and post times on specific events, any time of day they want. It's a great way to keep a group of friends competing with each other.

I do have one complaint: Dirt Rally could do with some optimization. Some stages play at a stable 120+ FPS, others might dip below 30 on the exact same settings, including weather. Setting weather to High (not Low, which is slower) and trees to Very Low helps. It's odd.

This game has some great voice acting. It's only one actor, he only plays one role, and he's your copilot. There's genuine nervousness in the way he reads his notes, at times he skips a beat and you just know going through all this he's pumped up on adrenaline. It's the perfect way to fill in the silence left by the menu music, and lends a lot to the game's serious racing atmosphere. Though the fact that he makes wrong calls is a bit unnerving. Not sure if that's a bug.

I heartily recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have always liked a casual dabble with an arcade racer, even a bit of Forza occasionally.  But, midway through a love affair with Driveclub I came across Dirt Rally.   That was a few weeks back and I haven't played anything since.  It's incredible and I didn't even realise that I liked sim rally racing.

It's definitely difficult but somehow that makes it more accessible, which is weird.  It's like the Dark Souls of racing games.  And it's a beauty to look at and runs extremely well on a pretty modest PC (1st gen i5 and 2Gb 7870 here).

I have hundreds of hours gameplay left with this game, and even after I've seen everything in the game, I can imagine playing this for a long time just because it's so exciting.

Lastly, I did have fun with a pad, but pretty soon I realised I needed a wheel so bought a secondhand Logitech DFGT for peanuts, and it's so much more satisfying and fun to play.  So, I'd recommend getting at least a budget FFB wheel and if you are on a budget I don't think the DFGT can be beat.

Not much to say that hasn't been said. It's the greatest rally game yet! Codemaster's really outdid themselves here and its awesome! Don't listen to the bad reviews that say its no fun with gamepad. The daily, weekly, monthly challanges are what makes this game especially great among the flawless sounds, physics, and immersiveness! I really like the fact that codemastered didn't make the game too graphically demanding that people with lower graphics cards like mine can still run it with no trouble! I appreciate that!

Things i would like to see:
-leaderboard scores for each individual country.
-racing each other's online ghosts on rally stages and championships like in colin mcrae rally 3 and i think 4.
-of course more rally locations, stages.

edit: would love an option to save my replays!

It's a short list because the game is already spectacular in early access! If you like racing games this is a must buy!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For now this is the best rally game since Richard Burns Rally. If everything goes well, it could be the best rally sim since RBR.
A pure rally sim is what we need after so many years.
//////////
Edit 2015/5/27:
For now, I have to change some of my previous thoughts about this game.
I've played almost all CodeMaster racing games except some F1 series, they all feel the same. CodeMaster made all their racing games feel like you are driving on ice. I feel better the days before Dirt, the whole EGO engine times. Dirt, dirt2, dirt 3, dirt count down, grid, grid 2, grid autosport, fuel, F1 2011, F1 2012, F1 2014, every EGO titles I can remember, they all feel the same---driving like on ice.
I think CodeMaster never hired some real driver to qualify the car physics, and almost every racing titles CM made are better controlled on joysticks/gamepads rather than on racing wheels. We invited many people who has deep real world driving experiences including some real racer to try out many CodeMaster racing titles both on gamepad and racing wheels. All of them can drive pretty good on racing wheels with racing sims like rFactor, iRacing, NFS13, Simbin titles, the new AC. But few of them feel good on any CodeMaster racing titles when driving with racing wheels. It just feels too fake on the car physics. CodeMaster racing games only perform good with controllers like gamepads.
Till now, after many hours of test drive in Dirt Rally, I admit everything goes better except car physics.
Is this one a Richard Burns Rally successor? Definitely not. Maybe some arcade racing fans would like this. But for a sim racer? Let's go back and play RBR.
I may change the advisory after its official release to Not Recommended". Just be prepared."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR Review: Essentially, it's the Dark Souls of racing games.

Full Review: I can happily max everything out on my system at 5120x1200 and it looks fantastic, both while driving and in the replays (i5 3570K & R9 280X). It's also challenging, in that thrilling way that is genuinely rewarding when you get it right. DiRT Rally is absolutely the best racing game I have played in a very long time.

I am not a hardcore racer (not even close), but there seem to be a lot of reviews saying it is purely a sim or that you should only play if you have a fancy wheel. While it does feel like there is a lot for the sim-heads, to me it feels very approachable using an Xbox pad, and that's without all of the assists turned on. As long as you are prepared to try and fail, there is a lot of fun to be had from this game no matter what your previous experience is. If you like to be out in front and coasting all the time, then maybe this isn't for you. If you like to push yourself to the limits, get DiRT.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of the best games I've been playing for a long time.

I'm into racing simulations since I can think, but with the most game you either have a good racing sim, OR a nice career mode. Until Dirt Rally came up that technically combines a realistic feel with nice graphics and a career mode and multiplayer leagues that is fun to play.

First of all, the support by the developers is OUTSTANDING. This is the first early access game that is fun to watch as it's doing a BIG progress with continuous updates and new non-DLC content. Frequently new stages, cars and even game modes have been released, handling is tweaked, bugs are fixed, performance improved - that's amazing. The developers really read the ideas and suggestions on the DIRT forums and implement respective functionality into the game. This is the first Early Access game where I can clearly feel the developers absolutely developing a game according to the player's feedback. So the many, many positive reviews here on Steam are very well deserved.

The handling:
I've been used to older Dirt games, but also played Richard Burns Rally a lot. RBR was supposed to be the most authentic rally sim and drifting in RBR was actually really easy. Somehow I believed that RBR is top of the notch and after playing Dirt Rally in a very early stage, I thought that Dirt Rally is far away from being realistic, because cars won't drift the way I want, engaging drifts and doing hairpins wasn't that easy as in other Rally Sims. However, the more I played, the more I noticed that the unrealistic" handling is actually only a result of my bad driving skills
date: because in Dirt Rally you actually have to know what you do with your car and how to set up your car to make it drift the way you want. The more you learn about car physics and rally driving techniques
recommended: the more you'll notice that Dirt Really is very accurate in simulating the car handling under specific conditions. You can really feel a big difference in the setup and the different car types such as AWD
hoursPlayed: RWD and FWD. You can use all sorts of real world driving techniques to get these different cars to slide the way you want and it works pretty accurate. Whenever you do a crash thanks to oversteering or understeering
voteText: there always is a logic explanation of what caused the car to behave that way. Thus said
helpfulPercent: after 25 hours of drifting and sliding through the game
votesHelpful:
I honestly consider this to be the most authentic handling when it comes to rally games.

The career mode:
The career mode is actually a really nice one
votesTotal: at the moment divided into Classic Rally (With co-driver)
votesFunny: Hill Climb (Without co-driver) and Rally Cross (The non-Dirt3-like realistic version). You're not going to participate in single events
commentsCount: but always in whole championships that are divided into different countries which again are divided into different rally stages. Once you're through all events and land on the podium on the end of the championship
column16: you're allowed to participate in a more advanced championship with of course more advanced AI opponents. Thus said
column17: the more you advance
column18: the more difficult it gets. So as a beginner
column19: you'll most likely have problems winning the first championship on the first try
column20: but on the second try you most likely will. The championship system always ensures you got a proper competition
column21: so the game is never too easy or too hard. It will keep you challenged
column22: but it's not too frustrating. Indeed it is very motivating because you can clearly see how you improve your times and driving skills during time until you reach the next championship level. Also you got the ability to repair your car each and every two stages you drove. Your mechanics got half an hour to repair a wide selection of different car parts
column23: all having an impact on the driving. If you drive stages at night
column24: you better repair the head lights of your car before you tweak the suspension. So you always have to make wise decisions on what you actually are going to repair during that half hour. However
column25: you can also entirely destroy your car so it's not repairable. If this happens
column26:
the championship is over and you'll loose everything.

Team management:
There is also the ability to manage your team. You can hire crew members
column27: and the more skilled these people are
column29: but therefor they need less time to repair specific car parts throughout the championship. You can check how long their contracts will run and you will have to make sure that none of the contracts is expiring during your championships. You can fire people
column31: and your team will even level up the more you drive in events. Good stuff: It's not important to win to level up your team and car
column32: but it's only important that you actually drive. The more KM you drove with team members hired
column33: the more they will progress and level up. So even if you got stuck on a specific difficulty
column34: driving and playing the games still provides a progress. If a specific member reached a level up
column35:
you have access to perks which you can buy to even improve the power of your team.

Car upgrades:
Another nice aspect is that when you play the championship events
column36: not just your team levels up
column37: but also your car. The more KM you've driven with the car with a specific team
column38: the more your team is going to know your car. So after some kilometers/time
column39: your team starts to install weight reductions/engine and turbo upgrades to your car. Means the more you drive an actual car in your garage
column40: the faster and more powerful it gets since your team keeps improving it. So even without winning championships
column41:
you're still earning money for new cars and upgrades for existing cars that make your favorite cars even faster.

Multiplayer leagues:
You can register and create an account on the RaceNet website
column42: allowing you to keep track of your progress and driving statistics
column43: comparing yourself to other real drivers and participate in online multiplayer events. Also you can race Rally Cross events together with other people on the same track
column44:
so you can actually crash and bump into them. This is nice to see your skills and times compared to other real world players.

Graphics:
Nothing much to say - the graphics are outstanding for a simulation game and look really good. On ultra settings on my machine it sometimes doesn't look exactly as nice as the preview images in Steam
column45: but generally the graphics are nothing someone can moan about.\n\nThat's all I had to say - this game is technically outstanding and unique in many
column46: many ways. Plus in some months there will even more features by the developers that have not been taken into account on this review. I can just recommend this game to ANYONE who is either a rally fan
column47: likes racing games in general or pure simulations. Everyone is going to have fun with this kind of game
column48: no matter if you like the simulation or if you want to play it with a game pad in an arcade style. Definitely a big recommendation from my side."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's been a long while since I've picked up a gamepad to play a driving game; indeed it's been a long time since there's been a driving game that I've been genuinely excited about. Having stumbled upon DiRT Rally, and having purchased the title on a whim, I'm can honestly say that the game has completely exceeded my expectations -- even in its current Early Access form.
I'm no seasoned racing-sim professional, not by any stretch; however, it seems that DiRT Rally is set to deliver a bona-fide rally driving experience in what is a serious departure from the arcadey, lowbrow mayhem for which the DiRT series has become known.
The game is visually gorgeous and the sound-design is spot on. But what's most impressive is the feel -- the handling of the vehicles, the physics, and the immersion. Although cliche, the game really is easy to play but difficult to master. It offers a challenging but highly rewarding experience that I've not known before in any racing title. Comparisons have already been drawn to Colin McCrae (also of Codemasters fame). Such comparisons are totally warranted.
There are some obvious limitations with the game at the moment. But far from being nit-picky I will let the development run it's course and post a more thorough review upon full release. I am more than satisified with my purchase to this point, and would definitely recommend the game to any seasoned rally-sim fans or even someone looking to try something new :)

reviewText:
I enjoy racing games that are challenging and has the realism factor to it. I've enjoyed the Collin MacRae series and the only other game to get close to that was the first Dirt, after that it's all been arcadey games which didn't make me feel like I've actually was doing anything.

This one is more than that and more, it has heart and it looks like the developers actually want to give us something out of their passion for the series and their roots.

I've only played close to two hours and I'm enjoying the career mode a lot, I really enjoy being able to repair and change my roster and things like that. Makes me feel like I'm in charge!

Looking forward to see where this game goes over the development period, highly recommended :)

---

Update: Now that the game is released, this is by far the best Early access game I had the joy to be part of. It's easily my favourite racing game now!

reviewText:
Brief summaryOf all current rally games, DiRT Rally is one truly great game for those looking for an exhilerating, intense and fun experience; therefore, it really is one of my favourite on-the-edge-of-the-seat driving games. There are a lot of cars and various real-life stages with the challenging bumps and road width, and the co-driver is generally excellent in guiding through stages. Cars generally feel and sound fantastic on gravel and snow. The only downside for me is the unrealistic tyre model and  abrupt dynamic behaviour on asphalt. On the whole, I would wholeheartedly recommend DiRT Rally to anyone to enjoys the exciting world of motorsports. 8.5/10.

_________

Cars and tracksThere are plenty of iconic rally cars from several classes, such as modern WRC machines, classic ‘70s, contemporary R4 cars to vehicles from the Group B era. In total, thirty-nine cars are available, and it is very noticeable that each have a specific handling. Thirty of these cars are available to drive in point-to-point rally stages. One particularly good aspect is that most of the cars sound very realistic in engine noise, and that they really seem to have a raw roar/irregularity to them as heard in their real-life counterparts. There is an upgrading system in the career mode; cars start out underpowered and overweight, and only after driving them several hundreds of kilometers, they will have the correct figures. Consequently, drivers that do not belong to the top 5% or so will have a hard time to win rally stages until they drive further.

In terms of tracks, currently there are six countries: Greece, Monaco, Finland, Sweden, Wales and Germany. Each country features two unique long stages, which are around the 10 km mark, or between the high six and low eight minutes of driving time, depending on driving skill. Smaller stages are just segments from all the main stages. Furthermore, the stages are also offered to be driven in backward direction for more variation. The best thing, however, is that these tracks are modeled after parts of real rally stages. Stages can be very bumpy and upsetting cars, and at times are very treacherously narrow. When the co-driver calls a ‘caution’, it is imperative to drive slower and more accurately in order to avoid crashes. In my opinion, this aspect really makes the game fantastic to play. The only downside is that stages tend to be somewhat repetitive since one rally can consists of short stages which appear again as longer stages. Additionally, players who play this game many, many hours will find that at one point the stages have become familiar and that a co-driver is not necessary anymore, which personally takes a slight bit of fun out of the game. From that point of view, it can be argued that more track variety is needed, but I feel that the game offers plenty of tracks for at least several tens of hours of fun.

Next to normal rallying, there are three rallycross circuits and a few special rallycross cars with up to 600 horsepower. Additionally, there is the Pikes Peak hillclimb, which is being offered in a fully-paved layout and a part gravel, part asphalt layout. Currently, there are a few historical hillclimb cars, such as the Audi Quattro S1 and the Peugeots 405 and 205 T16. Overall, content-wise there is much to offer, in my opinion.

Game modesThere is a career mode, in which rally stages are offered sequentially per country. While changing between countries, it is possible to switch cars. Online multiplayer is offered only in rallycross mode, sadly. For point-to-point rally stages, the only multiplayer component is comparing stage times with friends or the rest of the world. Furthermore, it is possible to setup specific leagues with set rules and regulations, and there are periodic events organized by the developers that offer nice moneraty rewards.

Co-driverOne of the best features in the game; the notes are clear and when set to ‘very early’, most of the time are very reliable in facilitating driving fast down a road that is not entirely familiar to the driver in advance. In high speed corners, the co-driver also talks faster and in a more severe tone, while he is calmer when driving slower. There are only a few slight mistakes in corner severity numbers being called, but overall the accuracy is very high. I find it a joy to drive without the HUD and being able to fully depend on the co-driver in this game.

Driving dynamicsAnother important aspect that has made the game so much fun for me is the handling. In basic terms of dynamics, the cars feel realistic; modern WRC machines are very neutral, have very short braking distances and carry enormous amounts of speed through corners with high control, whilst older rear-wheel drive cars (especially from Group B) are very twitchy and unforgiving under power, depending on the exact car model. While playing, it is not uncommon to spin under power, and avoiding such a spin is hugely satisfactory. All other cars sit in between these two extremes; generally, the older the car, the lower the overall stability of the cars during acceleration, braking and coasting. What I also like, is that any driving over the limit will result in brushing the walls or trees, often resulting in car damage or at the very least a loss of time. It makes the game challenging, but also very rewarding at the same time.

Personally, I find the handling of DiRT Rally on gravel (Wales, Greece, Finland) the most realistic: braking distances are longer now compared to the previous early-access handling and feel spot-on. Furthermore, cars do not loose too much momentum when sliding sideways through corners, but instead it is simulated that the wheels dig into the gravel surface and generate more lateral grip. The quantity of weight transfer (or actually wheel load transfer) on this surface feels the most accurate to me, because it is possible to make the car ‘dance’ between corners while being sideways. The same applies to pure snow and ice (Sweden and parts of Monaco); there is a fluidity in the cars handling that requires a certain precision in throttle, braking and steering inputs.

However, the cars may be too forgiving when exaggerating inputs, which brings me to the remaining surface: asphalt (Germany and parts of Monaco). This is where the game is at its weakest; there seems to be no realistic relation whatsoever between grip and slip angle (the difference between the angle of the front wheels and the general direction the car is travelling in). The problem is that there is a lot of grip when expected, but that grip loss happens very abruptly and untrue to rubber tyres on asphalt.  At higher speeds above 100 km/h or so, it is not too bad, since cars do grip and generally understeer under power when going too fast through a corner. However, at these speeds there is too little sideways slip, so driving sideways and having to correct with the steering in third gear or higher like in onboards videos on Youtube is sadly not possible. The lower speeds is where the handling simulations lacks the most: this is where the cars do oversteer, but the rate of angular acceleration is far too great to be believable. Unfortunately, this phenomenon also means that the best stage times are achieved with a lower steering angle settings since slides can be corrected quicker and unfrotunately, without a loss of stability. In real life, the fastest way would be balancing between too much and too little steering input, and for that reason, I personally always set my steering wheel at 900° of steering and therefore always lose some speed, even though the recommended by Codemasters is 540°, and the fastest people even use 270° or less. Despite this crazy car behaviour and optional 'physics cheat', the driving is still sufficiently enjoyable on tarmac. Still not great compared to gravel handling, but acceptible.

reviewText:
This game is punishing, and I adore it.

Nothing like any of the previous DiRT titles where you can just mash down the gas and steer for dear life although fun not realistic.  I found out very quick that you have to finely tune your vehicle and finesse it through every track, alot of skill to build in this game. At the time of this review I'm only sitting at around 15hrs or so but from what I can see there are a lot of tracks to race on and vehicles to unlock or should I say purchase.  Again it's nothing like any of the previous DiRT titles, it's an actual simulation now instead of an arcade game.  It's punishing, I'll say it again..IT'S PUNISHING.

Now you get a crew chief and get to hire and upgrade mechanics, in between stages you can repair your car.  The graphics are beautiful and the sound is great.  To be honest I was shocked when I first started playing, I couldn't do anything or keep my car on the road because I was so used to how the old DiRT titles played.  I stepped back took a deep breath and began to start respecting the game for what it had evolved into, an effing simulation.

Once I learned I had to tweak my car settings for every single track and gave the game respect I started picking it up and learning to drive again.  In the old DiRT series you really didn't have to make serious adjustments for most tracks anyways, in this game you really need to...or you will fail.  Also I read some other reviews about people playing with a M&K..not going to happen...you need a controller by default.  This game actually makes me want to go out and invest into a wheel and pedals, I have never ever considered that until now.  I'm about to take my nerd level up a notch.

I played DiRT 2 the most even after DiRT 3 was released since I was so ashamed of DiRT 3 and all of the Gymkhana whatever stuff they forced into a series of races.  Now that we are back to DiRT lets keep it here please, this game has redeemed the series and for that I am truly grateful.  The game just feels and looks and sounds so good, and there are a lot more customizable options now to your cars, I don't want to spoil it but you have to unlock" the good customization options. You are going to need them
date: the more you drive a car the more your team becomes familiar and the more unlocks for your customization abilities for that particular car you are granted.  The nice thing is all of the liveries are already unlocked giving you a little bit of flavor right off the bat
recommended: but the new customization replaces you being able to unlock paint jobs.\n\nThe game feels balanced
