voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Firstly do not expect to pick up this game and win right away...it's very unlikely! The game feels unforgiving at first but patience and practice begin to pay off after just a couple of hours.

The game is a superb blitz through Wales/Greece/Monte Carlo (at the moment) with Rally car through the ages. It's early access and more stages and hillclimbs are to come but there different styles and eras of cars keep you on your toes.

One thing to do for sure is to make use of the shakedowns where possible to fine tune the set up of your car and understand the feel of the surface.

I have been using Xbox controller for windows and have found this to be pretty decent although I imagine a wheel and pedal set up would give such a better feel.

Although early access this is already shaping up to be a classic and one of the best Rally games ever. Daily, weekly and monthly online challenges enable you to challenge yourself against the world which keeps things fresh and adds some further excitment.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Nearly jumped out of my seat, rubbed jelly on my chest and spanked like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ cow girl and threw my controller upon seeing such a beautiful thing! Never thought I would be so happy about getting 2nd place in a championship race. As I raced across the gravel kicking it up rocks and dirt at high speeds and cornering faster than I should of with a few love taps to the edges of death on the gravel/dirt roads, I managed to hold on with my pal Dave in the passenger seat. Me and Dave met at a party about 4 months ago and as soon as we glazed at one another we immediately knew we were meant for greatness. at first it was sorta ruff and couldn't catch a break, but that all changed on this day when everything would go right. We were both sweating in fear and adrenaline as we drifted on the narrow corners with our rear tires right on the edge of the cliff knowing if we fell off, it would be our deaths. The time was on the rise but we were doing good as we came to the final stretch we were overpowered by excitement of the finish line that we were going even faster which cause us to fishtail a little, but due to our tremendous love for one another and the road, the fishtail was no match for us and once we passed the finish line we glazed into each others lovely eyes and began to hug each other like it was our last.

And this is the story about how I was able to please the great gods of Asgoth!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Difficulty cranked to 11. As a long time fan of the DiRT series, this game caught me off-gaurd in all the best ways.

Incredibly unforgiving, realistic driving, no race trail. This game is no longer about speed as much as it is learning the call-outs, setting up your vehicle, and starting from the bottom up.

I will admit the grind seems very daunting at the moment, and in early access it'll get tedious, but it'll be well worth it I'm sure.

Glorious game. DiRT Rally brings rally racing back to its roots, and I'm excited for every turn.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nDeveloping and releasing a rally game nowadays must be a hard sell for a publisher. Not popular enough
date:
not enough sales" they might say. "We will never recoup our costs" they might say.

Releasing as early access they solved this politic issue and prolly got money when they needed it the most - for bug cleaning and tweaking.

Loving it so far. Handling is superb imho. Lots of adjustments can be made but you can also turn on some assists if you need that as well. Nice balance there. The graphics are beautiful on Ultra; wish I had 3 monitors and a wheel.

So happy the DIRT series didnt die and they went this route for the niche hardcores!

If you love rally support the developers and buy this game you won't be disappointed."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

WoW ! This game is the best rally game since RBR. And for Codies, since the 1st Colin Mcrae!

I've even not played GTA V since this came out! What more can you say!

I was not expecting this at all, after the direction Codies have been heading for the last 10 years or more. Previous Dirt games have been drivel IMO and F1 games not great either.

As for Dirt Rally, the physics feel pretty good, not quite up to the standard of iRacing,Assetto Corsa,rFactor 2. But it feels a million times better than anything Codies released for a long long time!
A bit of work on surface bumps and FF and it will be right up there.

I have a lot of sim racing gear. Fanatec CSW with V2 pedals. A Lightning SST H shifter, Triple screens. All this works with no fuss really. Multiple controllers are not a problem.

It really is much more rally like, like the real WRC rally. There are stages and all you do is Rally. apart from messiing with crew members which is pretty cool too. There's none of that other ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥te!

Thank you Codies! Please carry on making thisa a rally game, dare i say sim to be proud of!

11/10

voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A great racing (simulation) game. The graphics are not mind blowing but still very good, when you see the dust a few hundred meters behind you or the water splash driving through the muddy Wales. The Sound is amazing especially the historic cars sound like beasts. Sitting at the start with the Audi Quattro and the Stratos or the newly added Hillclimb cars, it's just an epic feeling listening to that monster sound. The Stages feel like real Rally stages and look quite similar to the real-life models. The handling feels alright, even tho it can still be twitched a bit along with the FFB.

Even tho it says Early Access, DiRT Rally feels more like a finished game that hasn't too much content at the moment. But there is a lot of content to come, next month there will be a German rally stage that puts you on a full tarmac course, and then later the summer Codemasters will add the biggest action motorsports has to show, with rallycross, to the game. Along with other content (also cars), there's no doubt that this can be the greatest rally game since and for a long time.

If in doubt

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is such an amazing game, I haven't had this much fun in a rally game for a long time. Has a great car lineup (with more to come), and all of them true classic rally vehicles. There are 36 stages so far with plenty of stages clocking in at 5+ minutes across Greece, UK/Wales and Monte Carlo. I'll be honest that I've spent most of my time playing the British rally, it's just such a nostaglia rush to have a Ford Escort RS Coswoth or Subaru Impreza blasting along the Sweetlamb stage. I started playing rally videogames with the DOS-based Network Q RAC Rallly Championship game from 1996, and getting to race these 90's Group A cars across Wales is a blast from the past!

Anyway, if you're a rally fan (particularly of the UK rally) then I would definitely give this game a look in. It's a difficult yet exciting take on the sport and a return to a more traditional rally game for the Dirt series which is very postivte I think. So get your wheel and pedals sets out and put your foot to the floor!  :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've played DiRT Rally for a couple of hours now and I've got to say that as a rally racing simulator, it is a vast improvement over the previous installments in the DiRT franchise. If you just casually played DiRT 2, 3, or Showdown, this probably isn't the arcade racer you are looking for. This is a legitimate Rally Sim. The career mode is much improved with a full team and realistic car damage.
I'm having a blast and it's only been in Early Access for a week now. I can't wait to see what else Codemasters brings to this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Dirt Rally, man... What a great game. It sure has it's own ups amd downs during the time of it's Early Access, such as bugs where the map doesn't load during the middle of the race and you be driving on nothing or fps problems with some update for myself but regardless of those few tiny problems that have came with the fact it is Early Access, this game is simple one of the best Dirt, CodeMaster and Rally games out there.
Forcefeed back on a wheel is just outstanding, maps are outstanding with every little detail matter to the driver and the Rally Call out guys details are close to prefect I can play without any osd (On Screen Display) and on a nre mape and still know where I am going. The detail of inside every car is a new feeling in cockpit view and third person you can really get to see the pretty liverys this game has, must be over 50 different ones for all the vicheals easy!
Pros :
Update a lot
It is just rally at its best, its scary and it is so fun.
Only game i've seen with a Hill Climb
A lot of choice to drive in and even maps with many more updates containing new maps
Feedback on wheel is amazing
Will have PVP
Anticheat for leaderboards (Also a con kinda since it not prefect yet but they will get it.)
They are trying for mod support which regardless if it happens or doesn't I think it matter they are trying.
Cons :
It sometime has fps problems with update
Just normal bugs that come with Early Access (They get fixed super fast though!)

For 40$ I think this game is well beon the money it cost, I feel like this game should cost like 60$ or more but its not, they only ask 40$ on your money and it is well worth it and if not! look steam gots refunds but I don't think you'll need them for this baby. Keep on rallying :) Hairpin turn coming up on left <3

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've always loved rallying. Through the butt-clenching hairpin turns on a track barely wider than your car, or the long stretches of track with trees on one side and a cliff edge on the other truly make rally racing an unique discipline. When Colin McRae's DiRT landed I was thrilled. A bit arcade-y, but it was an extremely fun game and was chock full of rallying goodies.  Unfortunately, the series took a downward spiral of depression, and started gaining unnecessary weight through the use of Ken Block, gymkhana, and developed diabetes from a general Dude-bro" attitude to the sport.

Thankfully
date: Codemasters released DiRT Rally. DiRT Rally cuts off all that extra and unnecessary weight
recommended: and throws everything wrong with DiRT 2
hoursPlayed: DiRT 3 and DiRT Showdown out the window and focuses on pure rallying with no extra B.S.\n\nIf you want Gymkhana
voteText: Ken Block
helpfulPercent: Explosions
votesHelpful: Fireworks
votesTotal: Rewinds

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I saw this game on steam, I was both excited and worried. I was excited that the there was a new DiRT game coming out and that it was going to be focused on rally however I was also scared that it wouldn’t live up to my expectations. I finally made the decision to buy it and I was so happy to make that decision. It is the most fun early access game I have played since kerbal space program. Another worry I had about this game was that it would be unplayable with a controller but that is not true. The game is perfectly playable with a controller, however every day I own this game the temptation to buy a force feedback wheel grows. I love how this game feels and the way the can completely upset the cars balance. Although there aren’t that many cars and stages yet they are all high quality and there will be more to come in future updates.
All is not well though, as with all of these positives there must be some negatives. Most of the things that I have disliked about this game are all the symptoms of an early access release and most of them have been fixed or will be fixed. The bugs I have experienced with this game have been mostly Co-driver related and they are all fixed quickly by the next update.
In the end I am very happy I have bought this game as not only has it been fun but it has been a learning curve, helping me progress my ability. I can’t wait to see what this game will become in the future.

9/10 would buy again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just recently got a better rig for playing games, and was trying to find a good racing sim. Got it as a part of an AMD promotion and already fell in love with it. Setting up a crew and progressing through the game feels particularly rewarding, and the handling on the car feels pretty natural, even on a gamepad.

My favorite part however is that the upgrades aren't linear, which is a problem that plagues racing sims. If a racing game allows customization at all, it usually follows that there is a certain set of upgrades one should get to optimize their car, and that's it. With vehicle progression being based on the crew you choose, I can see myself dumping hours into this game to see how different crews work out for different cars.

May not have invested to much time into the game, but I love racing games and this already seems like a blast. If I had more time, I would be no lifing it right about now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

DiRT was a great game; variety, depth, and style combined to deliver one of the best racing titles in memory. The series took a step away from simulation with DiRT 2, using a more arcade-y physics package, gimmicky races and locations, and tacky cameos from Pastrana and Block. DiRT 3 and Showdown...more of the same, if not even worse.

Finally, Codemasters brings us back to the glory days, giving us a rally game worth playing. No nonsense, unforgiving (to a fault at points, and yes, Wales, I'm speaking of you), visually impressive, and just plain fun. I've barely gotten into the game, yet I've found myself with white knuckles multiple times in a Mini with barely 100 horsepower. Looking forward to seeing the finished product.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Codemasters finally returned to their roots, and it's glorious as ever! Fantastic rally game with the learning curve of actually trying to race a real event (haven't really done it but can assume I'd end up wrapped around a tree at the first turn). Seriously don't expect to pick this up and be a pro first run, but given time, this game will have you feeling more than ready to go hit some back roads at 90mph. I bought a T300 and playseat challenge as soon as I saw this was out and will never look back. I couldn't imagine playing this with a controller but I see people do and post better times than me so it's definitely possible.
Tips: start slow enough to consistently finish stages without wrecking and slowly, very slowly watch your times increase. I've spent 20 hours with this game and just now got second in my first career open rally series. I can't stop playing. Too good. All time favorite racing game. Period.
Rally racing at its finest in such a long time it's almost as if this is the only rally game that's ever existed. Buy now and expect to wreck repeatedly.
Would ruin my best time ever on the last corner over and over again.

reviewText:
I have over 100 hours now and its safe to say this is the most Addicting Dirt game since before DIrt 2. There are many Pro's and COn's to this game and i think they deserve to be fairly listed.

Pro's
+No Ken Block, no drift events, no annoying announcers
+Probably the best Rally sim out since RBR
+ Gorgeous Tracks
+Beautifully Detailed Cars
+ Realistic Car Handling and FFB (Especially with a wheel)
+ Choice and Category of Cars
The overall feel of the cars and the tracks alone make this game worth playing.

Cons
-Unforgiving racing simulator (Not full Sim but not very far off either. Firmly in 80% + sim territory)
Note the Above is a drawback for those not into Sim's
-In game Economy mode needs work, new players are excluded from so much without doing SIngle Event
-Immersion is ruined by botched physics and object interaction. This is when you hit something in the game. Mud is basicaly ice and can rol you at 15MPH no matter what car you are in... wodden signs that if you hit stick to you and you cant go faster than 40 MPH, tire damage that is cringe inducing, in certain cars simply spinning out and bumping a tree with your rear means a flat. Maybe 2.
-The selection of Cars, most of the classics are in game, but there is a fair few from Group A or the 2000's that are still missing.
-Leagues are entirely non-functional at the moment.
-- Personally, i dont feel the game is finished and as such had no right to move out of early access. The game is AWESOME to play, just about all the major bases are covered, but so many little things in the game are broken or non-functional that it sours the experience.

Verdit 7/10 (10 is possible) due to bugs,glitches and the general unfinished nature of the game as of Jan 2016.
Probably not worth the 60 $ it is now, as PC gamers when we purchase a product for 60 $ we expect it to be done. Seeing as i bought my way into early access at 32.49, i in no way feel cheated and feel 40 $ is a good price for what has been achieved so far.

What does this mean for a poor rally fan? -------->BUY IT ON SALE.<--------
:D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Blog post[uberswe.com] | YouTube Video

Dirt Rally is considered among the best rally games for the PC at the moment and the game isn't even done yet. A lot of work has also been put into making a steering wheel feel realistic when playing this game, unfortunately I only have an xbox controller, either way the gameplay is awesome and it feels really good to play. It feels like a realistic rally game should and is a great relief after having to deal with dissapointments like Dirt Showdown, not saying that it was a terrible game but it was not what I had hoped for when new Dirt games came out.

Menus feel great, seems like I can't click anything with my mouse which is fine, you end up navigating with your controller or keyboard. The customization is pretty cool, you pick your own team to work with you on your car and races, different team members may be better at some things compared to others which can affect how good your car is for example.

Once you enter into a championship you can customize your car further by changing things like breaking, gears, cambers and more. The game tries to be pretty realistic, as you go up to the start you will need to hold the handbrake as the timer counts down, however, there is nothing stopping you from letting go of the handbrake and actually going early. Didn't check if this earns you a penalty, but I would assume it is not a good thing to do. If you were to drive backwards on the track you actually end up being disqualified from the championship which was interesting and costly. I also liked how any damage to your car is kept throughout the race from every collision.

Getting familiar with controls was easy, they felt pretty standard, I played on the hardest difficulty which made it a bit hard to steer and break but after a while I got used to it. Finding the handbreak and learning to use it correctly in turns also helps a lot. I also noted that when I went off a really high cliff where my car could not be recovered I actually ended up losing the race which I thought was awesome because the game is right, I shouldn't be able to keep going if my car falls off a cliff.

Overall I really like this game, I don't have anything negative to say about it at this time and I definitely recommend buying it, especially if it is on sale.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My take on Dirt Rally (pre order release):

Two words or less: Merciless Fun.

The good, the bad, the ugly and the indifferent:

Can't speak to controller land, I don't equate controller and SIM at all; it's like an oxymoron. That said, it's not really a SIM, it's a very serious game with some decent underpinnings and good enough visuals to get the job done. Be prepared to play with the FFB settings to get rid of the muddled center and spring action and tweak the rest of it to get what you want. Well at least get it close enough... Once tweaked the FFB is as passable as AC or Race Room; canned as the day is long but giving the appropriate info. This is with  the base Fanatec 4za" wheel with an Elite pedal set
date: other wheels will vary.\n\nOne thing I lament right off the rip is the fact the wheel button/pedal schemes are cast in cement. It's 2015 not 1995... They say they're going to address this for different wheels which is great news
recommended: however I have to wonder if that will include telling the game I want to use a particular pedal or button for something regardless of input device. I am really hoping they get beyond the control schema looking at me stupid with a face full of "you want teh clutch pedal to do what..?" (...a clutch pedal that isn't usable in my pedal set ATM to boot
hoursPlayed: again something they purpose to fix...) The flexibility to add stand alone shifters and e-brakes for custom cockpits will go a long way towards immersion and aren't something I'd consider optional in this day and age
voteText: it would be a detriment to the title to leave this kind of thing out again.\n\nWhile we're weeping and wailing and gnashing teeth
helpfulPercent: the menu still being straight out of console land for a PC title is a bit bonehead classification worthy. You'll need to drag out your wheel manual and note what buttons are what numbers. Once I figured out where the buttons were it was navigable
votesHelpful: I could even change the liveries with my shifter paddles. It's not like you can't get from here to there in the game on a wheel; it's just a PITA to do so on some occasions. I was able to use the keyboard as well
votesTotal: I had no issues mixing and matching the return and escape buttons into the wheel button mix at first. Once I got the hang of all the buttons the keyboard was able to be set aside. I shouldn't have to work so hard to get through a menu
votesFunny: mouse support should be like 2 or 3 on the list of things to fix/improve/implement. It's a PC game
commentsCount: it needs PC control.\n\nThe environment and atmosphere are done very well. Track side is lively enough yet not overbearing or intrusive. The graphics are dated but look just fine in play mode as I flail the wheel in 3rd hanging on for all I've got. Replays don't look quite as good
column16: but are more than passable for me. I think they hired GT5 to make a guest appearance or something. While the surroundings look very good
column17: the cars are aliased and a bit blocky and the damage model looks to be lifted straight from Kaz' special vault. Gotta love elongated oval lights that stretch like silly putty after an incident...\n\nSpeaking of damage... The "get some and have to repair it" side is perfectly done. It's not a stretch to have to swap tires
column18: re-balance them or replace a cracked/stressed/bent rim. Clogged filters
column19: oil changes
column20: damage to the body and cooling systems or brakes that took a beating on a particularly bad section. All of this is there in a simple slider system. You repair them with Time
column21: allotting what you can to whatever you want to fix. It all works well enough
column22: isn't overly complicated
column23: calls for some strategic decision making and acts as a wear and tear factor in addition to damage. At the end of a stage
column24: money is subtracted from your winnings to bring the car back up to snuff for the next event. Again
column25: a simple solution that's just enough to make for some nice extra immersion.\n\nI like how the crew expands and affects the car under you
column26: just enough to give the "elite team" feel without going overboard. Throw in the simplified team management of hiring engineers and there is enough to give the game that little bit of extra depth. It's not like the game will collapse into a black hole without these features
column27: but to me they are just enough to complete the whole Driver-Team-Race Day feel into a nice cohesive package that really helps establish immersion before I ever hit the track.\n\nI love the fact you can screw up. Royally. Like blow an entire stage or event due to being daft at the controls. In most minor incidents you can recover with a time penalty
column28: a slight of hand that mimics the fans rolling you over or pushing you back to the stage so you can continue. However there are times when as a driver you really mess up and go too far off or do too much damage to continue. In those cases that's it
column29: you're done. I'm glad the game has the stones to flirt with this kind of stark reality
column30: I've already seen too many cries of take it out. I hope they don't. Really makes me appreciate the times when I get it right
column31: and let's face it; nothing makes you learn how to drive better and use your head more than a couple DNFs.\n\nThe drive physics feel very good
column32: they equate quite well to my real life experiences in similar conditions. The FFB gives me enough but could do so much more in this area
column33: the information is somewhere between basic and detailed once the wheel is tweaked. I don't find issue with the braking
column34: in a straight line with a vehicle specifically equipped for the conditions it's not surprising to see the level of performance the game gives. Where I look is when the car is out of shape and you ask it to do something it shouldn't be able to do. The first time you try to stomp the pedal while being slightly sideways and find it only makes you go more sideways and you find the road really isn't as wide as it looks and that trees and gravity are not your friends it begins to sink in that maybe the brakes aren't as good as you thought. I find the throttle control is very good
column35: very much fun. Ripping the hairpins with the e-brake and powering out is a blast
column36: feathering the throttle for that last bit of speed as you bob and weave and hang on is quite satisfying. The car hangs on quite well
column37: at least as long as you are on the course.\n\nThere is one behavior I find peculiar

column39: heavy snow or deep gravel I can see it

column41: something that would be in play with short

column44: and it's really well done. I love it when I get into fast or tight sections and I can get him to stutter or get a bit confused. Don't know if it's intentional or if the game is just trying to cue up files for the next corners
column45: but hearing him fumble about just adds that little extra edge of urgency and immersion for me. I hope it stays that way.\n\nOver all the game is a bucket load of fun. I'm not constantly harassed by console energy drift garbage

reviewText:
[1.0 Release, 08 December 2015:] Now that Early Access is over I can wholeheartedly recommend this game. Nearly all of the issues I had with DiRT Rally have been ironed out throughout the year, with my final biggest gripes being sorted in version 1.0.

This is a wonderful representation of Rally with a great selection of cars from the history of the sport. I'd love more locations, but the stages that have been included are very high quality and provide an excellent greatest hits" of what rallying around the world has to offer. I am very pleased with their decision to model real-world stages.

The actual driving experience (using G27) is simply one of the best pieces of computer-based entertainment I have experienced. I said something similar in my initial review below
date: but this has only improved in my eyes.\n\nThe RX and Pikes Peak content are nice extras to the game. It'd be great if this project leads to a new licenced rallycross title that continues with the more "authentic"/"sim" approach to modelling the sport and includes the full World RX season
recommended:
as well as a "sequel" to DiRT Rally that simply has a larger selection of rally locations with a bigger budget.

DiRT Rally is an excellent title. If you have any interest at all in the sport (and ideally a wheel) and are prepared to fail a lot (all part of the fun!) then this is well worth the purchase.




[22 May 2015:] My rule of thumb in judging an Early Access game: "If development were to stop right now
hoursPlayed: would I be happy with my purchase?" In this case
voteText: it's a definite yes.\n\nAnd luckily
helpfulPercent: development is on track to add a lot more and produce a truly fantastic game once 1.0 comes around. I am impressed with the way the development team is handling community feedback and it seems they are listening to the right things.\n\nIn its current form it still has its problems
votesHelpful: particularly the FFB
votesTotal: but the main ones have been acknowledged by the dev team and fixes/improvements are in the works.\n\nIt is not easy
votesFunny: but in my opinion that is the way it should be in a game aiming to be a rally "sim". I am not super skilled at sims
commentsCount: but play with a wheel and no assists
column16: and I have only won two stages in career mode so far (over 30 hours). But that doesn't matter
column17: as my gradual improvement has been one of the most rewarding things I have experienced in a game.\n\nDespite a few flaws at this stage of development
column18: my time spent with the game in the first few weeks has been some of the most fun I have ever had at a computer."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis truly is the best rally game since Richard Burns Rally. The cars feel very real to drive, and the sounds and graphics are also very impressive. My current graphics card struggles to run the game on Ultra though, but I do it anyways, since it looks so good on Ultra. I run it on Ultra with my Gtx 560 Ti 2GB, and fps differs in each stage, but it's mostly about 30 fps or so. I drive in cockpit view, using an Xbox 360 controller, and man, it just feels fantastic. The only problem I have with this game so far is the damage model. It's still far away from being as realistic as Richard Burns Rally's damage model. I would also like to see specifically which parts are damaged, like which parts of the engine are damaged for example, not just a health bar for the overall engine damage, and you should be able to fix the different parts seperately like in Richard Burns Rally. Well anyways, the game is excellent, and I am glad I bought it. I can only see it getting better and better.

My congratulations to all the development team, especially the software team (just because I am a former software developer !)
I highly recommend this game, no doubt that this game will be a reference for rally racing simulation.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nHoly ♥♥♥♥! I haven't liked racing games for soo long. But this game is something else. It looks SO realistic (maxxed out in 1080p) and the car handles like a real vehicle. I play from helmet view and the steering wheel (in-game) shakes with the ground realistically, the rumble in the 360 is realistic to the point you can drive based on it (just like in real life when off roading and feeling the road in your steering wheel), the weight of the vehicle is spot on, the sense of speed is spot on, oh my gawd I totally enjoy this game. The VERY FIRST TIME I played it i didn't crash but did a great lap! My real life driving skills (which are superrrb) translated perfectly into the game. I'm awestruck. This is so much fun I can't put it down. Even if you don't like racing games, GET THIS NOW. This is next gen ^2. It's remarkable. Ok. It's 4:36 am. Time to stop playing. Good night.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's still early access but this game is shaping up to be awesome. I've played pretty much every rally game that's come out for the PC since the late 90's, Mobil 1 Rally Championship, Colin McRae, Dirt, Richard Burns Rally, you name it I've played them and this is up there with RBR and M1RC as one of the greats.

Handling feels pretty realistic in that cars aren't on rails, you can't let off the gas to make every turn at near full speed, damage is pretty realistic in that a slight off can puncture a tire and do some bad damage. The stages are longer than in DIRT but not nearly as long as M1RC or even some RBR stages, but they're decently long at about 6-8 minutes for the majority.

There are a lot of different types of cars and they do feel realistic for their age, ie: modern WRC cars are insanely fast and handle a lot better than some of the early FWD rally cars (Mini).

If you want a really good rally game that looks pretty pick this up as soon as you can, I don't think you'll regret it.
